description: From Middle English child, from Old English ƒãild, from Proto-West Germanic *kil√æ, *kel√æ, from Proto-Germanic *kel√æaz (‚Äúwomb; fetus‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *«µelt- (‚Äúwomb‚Äù).

Cognate with Danish kuld (‚Äúbrood, litter‚Äù), Swedish kull (‚Äúbrood, litter‚Äù), Icelandic kelta, kjalta (‚Äúlap‚Äù), Gothic êå∫êåπêåªêå∏êå¥êåπ (kil√æei, ‚Äúwomb‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§ú‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ (jarta), ‡§ú‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å (j√°rtu, ‚Äúvulva‚Äù).

nouns.description: child (plural children or (dialectal or archaic) childer)

definitionGroups.group: (broadly) A person who has not yet reached adulthood, whether natural (puberty), cultural (initiation), or legal (majority).

entries.meaning: (pediatrics, sometimes, in a stricter sense) A kid aged 1 to 11 years, whereas neonates are aged 0 to 1 month, infants are aged 1 month to 12 months, and adolescents are aged 12 years to 18 years.
examples: Regular chores can be appropriate for both children and adolescents, given age-appropriate limits on difficulty level and time on task.
Coordinate terms: newborn, neonate, infant, adolescent, teenager, teen

entries.meaning: (with possessive) One's direct descendant by birth, regardless of age; one's offspring; a son or daughter.
examples: My youngest child is forty-three this year.
His adult children visit him yearly.

entries.meaning: A person considered a product of a place or culture, a member of a tribe or culture, regardless of age.
examples: He is a child of his times.

entries.meaning: Anything derived from or caused by something.
(computing) A data item, process, or object which has a subservient or derivative role relative to another.
examples: The child node then stores the actual data of the parent node.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of childe (‚Äúyouth of noble birth‚Äù)
(mathematics) A subordinate node of a tree.
(obsolete, specifically) A female child, a girl.

description: From Middle English childen, from the noun child.

verbs.description: child (third-person singular simple present childs, present participle childing, simple past and past participle childed)

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive, intransitive) To give birth; to beget or procreate.
